error.signature: OCI runtime create failed: cgroup limit reached

verdict.summary: Container exceeded cgroup resource limits (memory, CPU, or PIDs). The kernel OOM killer terminated the process or Docker refused to start the container.

dead_ends.action: Running the container with --privileged to bypass cgroup limits
dead_ends.why_fails: Privileged mode does not bypass cgroup memory limits; it grants device access but the OOM killer still enforces memory constraints

dead_ends.action: Disabling the OOM killer with --oom-kill-disable without setting memory limits
dead_ends.why_fails: Without memory limits, the container can consume all host memory and freeze the entire system

workarounds.action: Increase the container memory limit: docker run -m 2g
workarounds.how: docker run -m 2g --memory-swap 4g <image> â€” sets 2GB RAM limit with 4GB total (including swap)

workarounds.action: Profile the container to find the memory-hungry process
workarounds.how: docker stats <container> to see real-time memory usage; docker exec <container> top to identify the process
workarounds.condition: when the container genuinely needs optimization

leads_to.condition: when OOM killer terminates the container process

preceded_by.condition: when disk and memory pressure occur together

frequently_confused_with.distinction: Cgroup limit errors happen at container start or when limits are explicitly hit, while exit code 137 is the result after OOM kill happens to a running container
